title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 4
scripture_ref: ‘The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”
scripture_text: Success in ministry will not produce lasting joy.
devotional:
We all want to be successful in our ministry; we all want to be effective for God which is not a bad thing. However, sometimes we fall for the lie that says, ‘I would be happier if I was more effective for God.’ We convince ourselves that our happiness depends on us being successful in ministry. We all have this driving desire to be noticed, to be seen, we have a built-in fear of not achieving. We want to be seen to be making a difference for God.

Tim Keller wrote:-

‘Today there is far more pressure than ever before on ministers to be “successful.” The very idea of success is something of a new way to judge ministers. The older criteria for evaluation had more to do with doctrinal accuracy, loyalty, and consistency of discharging duties. But no one can deny that these measurements have been eclipsed by the criteria of success. Today’s churches and congregations seek successful ministers and dismiss less successful ones. It is also true that ministers hold themselves to the standards of success of increasing numbers and expanding budgets. Source unknown.

Some of us are perfectionists, we put so much pressure on ourselves to get everything right, and we have a fear of failure that is really a subtle expression of selfish self protection. Did you know that although Jesus was perfect, he was secure enough not to be a perfectionist. One of the most difficult lessons to learn in Christian ministry is to learn how not to turn your ministry into a necessity for life. In our warped way of thinking we often relate success in ministry or life with the approval of God. We think, ‘God must really love me, look how he is blessing what I am doing!’

There is nothing wrong in wanting to be successful in what God has called you to do. But as we have seen, it becomes wrong when the ministry becomes the source of our identity, significance and joy.

Sometimes our Christian service can become an idol, or a trap, and we end up with ‘ministry addiction.’ It can become something we selfishly pursue in order to medicate the ache in our own hearts that we dare not acknowledge or speak about. But God has created us for something that is much greater than success.

Those who link their joy with being successful in ministry are skating on thin ice. What Jesus is saying here is so radical, he is saying, do not look to success, or to ministry to give you joy in this life. He is saying successful ministry will never make you happy. It is very easy for any of us to get our ministry out of perspective; it is easy to fall into the trap where your ministry becomes too important. The real battle we all face is to hold our ministry lightly, not taking it too seriously, refusing to be defined by what we do. Sometimes ministry can become too important because we have lost our passion for God.

All ministry is not successful. Joshua Wilson pastor of Vankleek Hill Baptist Church wrote: -

‘Failure in ministry is generally spoken of in terms of moral failure. We read of the addictions, the affairs, the plagiarism, the misuse of money, and the spiritual abuse in leadership, and we are rightly shaken. However, there are pastors and leaders who commit no moral failure, but perceive that their ministry has failed. This is a different category altogether. What happens when you put your hand to the plough, but the visible outcome of what you do is meagre or non-existent?

What does it mean when you pursue your calling, minister with all the strength that Jesus supplies, preach the gospel, love people, and it just doesn’t work out?

Where did it all go wrong? More precisely, you may ask. What did I do wrong? Wrestling with these questions, my own thoughts grew increasingly dark, leading to the crippling and overwhelming sense of total failure.’ https://www.thegospelcoalition.org/article/the-haunting-of-ministry-failure/. Accessed 26/04/2025.

Often we see this in the bible.

When God called Isaiah he was told that he will be ignored (Isaiah 6).

Ezekiel was prophesying in exile, God tells him not to be afraid of the people he will speak to, and warns him that failure is distinctly possible, because, ‘The people to whom I am sending you are obstinate and stubborn.’ (Ezekiel 2:4)

Jeremiah suffered intense emotional, and physical, distress. ‘Whenever I speak, I cry out proclaiming violence and destruction. So the word of the Lord has brought me insult and reproach all day long. But if I say, “I will not mention his word or speak any more in his name,” his word is in my heart like a fire, a fire shut up in my bones. I am weary of holding it in; indeed, I cannot.’ (Jeremiah 20:8-9)

It is a bit ironic that Jonah the disobedient prophet was one of the most successful prophets. He reluctantly preached an eight word sermon and the great city of Nineveh repented.

There seems to be little recognition that often in Christian ministry, despite a persons faithfulness and devotion, that there is no guarantee of having a ‘successful’ outcome. This is why we need to find our joy in our relationship with God.

This does not mean that we cannot rejoice when or if God chooses to use us. We should be grateful for those occasions. However, if the fear of failure dominates our thinking and drives our emotions, then the success we desperately seek indicates that our ministry has become all about us.
prayer: Prayer. Father help find my life and joy in my relationship with you
